refnamediv.refpurpose: Produces a result array whose set of cells consists of every possible combination of a cell from one source array and a cell from another source array.

refsect1.title: Summary
refsect1.para: The cross operator calculates the full cross product of two arrays. If the left array has m dimensions and the right array has n dimensions, the result array will have m + n dimensions. If the left array has x non-empty cells and the right array has y non-empty cells, the result array will have x Ã— y non-empty cells.

For example, consider a 2-dimensional array A with dimensions i, j, and a 1-dimensional array B with dimension k. Within the result array produced by cross(A,B), the cell at coordinate position {i, j, k} is the concatenation of cell {i, j} of A with cell {k} of B.

If the two source arrays have a pair of like-named variables (i.e., attributes or dimensions), the result array will include one variable with that name and another variable with that name plus the suffix "_2."
If a cell of one source array is empty, all associated cells in the result array will be empty.

informalexample.para: This example returns the cross product of two 1-dimensional arrays, each of which includes only one attribute.

step.para: Show the first array: --afl create array letters <letter:string> [i=0:2,3,0] --show-query=no --show-output=no --shell --command=csv2scidb -s 1 -p S < ../examples/letters.csv > ../examples/letters.scidb --show-query=no --show-output=no --aql load letters from '../examples/letters.scidb' --show-query=no --show-output=no --afl scan(letters);

informalexample.para: This example returns the cross product of two 1-dimensional arrays, one of which has multiple attributes.

step.para: Show the first array: --afl create array lettersPlus <letter:string, type:string> [i=0:2,3,0] --show-query=no --show-output=no --shell --command=csv2scidb -s 1 -p S < ../examples/lettersPlus.csv > ../examples/lettersPlus.scidb --show-query=no --show-output=no --aql load lettersPlus from '../examples/lettersPlus.scidb' --show-query=no --show-output=no --afl scan(lettersPlus);
Generate the cross product with the array called "numbers":--afl cross(numbers,lettersPlus); --output-format=auto --chunkify=yes

informalexample.para: This example returns the cross product of two 1-dimensional arrays, one of which includes some null-valued attributes.

step.para: Show the array containing some null values (where the even numbers would be): --afl create array oddNumbers <number:int64 null> [i=0:4,5,0] --show-query=no --show-output=no --shell --command=csv2scidb -s 1 -p N < ../examples/oddNumbers.csv > ../examples/oddNumbers.scidb --show-query=no --show-output=no --aql load oddNumbers from '../examples/oddNumbers.scidb' --show-query=no --show-output=no --afl scan(oddNumbers);
Generate the cross product with the letters array:--afl cross(oddNumbers,letters); --output-format=auto --chunkify=yes

informalexample.para: This example returns the cross product of two 1-dimensional arrays, one of which includes some empty cells.

step.para: Show the array containing some empty cells (where the odd numbers would be): --afl store(build_sparse(<number:int64>[i=0:4,5,0],i,((i%2)=0)),evenNumbers) --show-query=no --show-output=no --afl scan(evenNumbers);
Generate the cross product with the letters array:--afl cross(evenNumbers,letters); --output-format=dense --chunkify=yes
